talk.author: did:plc:lvm56rdpwaumi3jezsqesky4
talk.utter: I never read any Enid Blyton books, but was quite aware of them as a thing. Even as a kid, don't know exactly why, but I disdainfully regarded them as being "twee." A silly, unfounded, irrational prejudice maybe, or perhaps something radar-like that's attuned to sussing out drivel. Who knows?

talk.author: did:plc:tbaycr3xjlfplnwv5rmi7wiy
talk.utter: I've always been aware of books I decided to read for one reason or another. One big perk of my current job is getting to see books I might not have known about otherwise.

talk.author: did:plc:lvm56rdpwaumi3jezsqesky4
talk.utter: There's often a strange entanglement of serendipity involved in the selection of books, or for that matter, just stumbling upon some wonderfully random find at a neighborhood "little library."

talk.author: did:plc:lvm56rdpwaumi3jezsqesky4
talk.utter: There's often a strange entanglement of serendipity involved in the selection of books, or for that matter, just stumbling upon some wonderfully random find at a neighborhood "little library."

talk.author: did:plc:tbaycr3xjlfplnwv5rmi7wiy
talk.utter: That's part of why I enjoy checking used book shops and library sales. I've found single titles and parts of series that I wound up really enjoying.

talk.author: did:plc:lvm56rdpwaumi3jezsqesky4
talk.utter: Generally speaking, I find "shopping" a thoroughly tedious experience, but not when it comes to books; then it's a whole different ball game. And yeah, thrift shops/library sales are great opportunities for making new and unexpected discoveries.
